items.message: The heavy rain from yesterday cleared the area in the early hours of the morning and no further rain is forecast today, 21/09/2025. River levels are falling and are expected to continue to fall throughout the day. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, but there may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible this afternoon, Sunday 21st September, and for at least the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth which is restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 22nd September, or as the situation changes.

The heavy rain from yesterday cleared the area in the early hours of the morning and no further rain is forecast today, 21/09/2025. River levels are falling and are expected to continue to fall throughout the day. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, but there may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Wyke Beck and Meanwood Beck catchments
items.message: River levels have peaked and are falling on Wyke Beck and Meanwood Beck following heavy rainfall in the evening and overnight on Saturday 20th September 2025. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days. River levels are expected to continue to fall throughout today and into tomorrow, 22nd September 2025, and therefore this Flood Alert is no longer in force. Please be aware that standing water may still remain on low-lying land and roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if required over the next few days.

River levels have risen at the at Whitewater Bridge Gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton. No further rainfall is forecast. River levels at Whitewater Bridge Gauge will remain high until this afternoon, 21/09/25. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 today 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Rye Catchment, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Land around the River Rye and it's tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck, including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on Sunday, 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Boyces Brook and Duddel Brook at Ribchester, Ribblesdale Road and Church Street areas
items.message:
Flooding is expected from 10:30 PM on 20/09/2025.
Areas most at risk include Boyces Brook and Duddel Brook at Ribchester, Ribblesdale Road, Church Street and Sunnyside Avenue areas.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 11:30 AM on 21/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech peaking at 4.43m Sunday morning, Cae Howel 2.5m to 3.0m Sunday evening 21/09/25.   
No further rainfall is forecast in next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Monday 22/09/25.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 5pm Sunday 21/09/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Basford  Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on Sunday 21 September 2025.
We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 21 September 2025. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 16:00 on 21 September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 1:15pm today, Sunday 21st September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.76 mAODN at 12:15pm on Sunday 21st September, which is 0.46m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5:00pm today, Sunday 21st September.

The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides for this evenings tide, Sunday 21st September. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue this alert if necessary.

High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible around the high tide from 7:00 PM today 20/09/2025.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley of 6.16 mAODN at 07:00 PM on 20/09/2025, with westerley force 6 winds
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.
After this evenings high tide, the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are checking flood defences and closing flood gates.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 11:00 AM on 28109/2025.
All times are in British Summer Time
